title: How to find the mean and variance of a Skellam distribution (difference of a Poisson distribution) - Quora

response.answer_text: As you said, Skellam distribution is the distribution of the difference of two independent Poisson distributions. That is, let [math]N_1[/math] and [math]N_2[/math] be two independent random variables following Poisson distributions with [math]\mu_1[/math] and [math]\mu_2[/math], respectively, and you want the mean and variance of [math]N=N_1-N_2[/math]. A Poisson distribution with parameter [math]\mu[/math] has mean and variance being both [math]\mu[/math]. Mean: [math]E(N)=E(N_1-N_2)=E(N_1)-E(N_2)=\mu_1-\mu_2[/math] by additivity of expectation. Variance: [math]Var(N)=Var(N_1+(-N_2))=Var(N_1)+Var(-N_2)=Var(N_1)+Var(N_2)=\mu_1+\mu_2[/math] by the fact that the variance is additive when the random variables are independent.

Since it is the difference of two Poisson distribution, the expectation and the variance can be worked out by simple arithmetic. Eg., if [math]X \sim Poisson(\lambda)[/math] and [math]Y \sim Poisson(\mu) [/math]independently, then we have [math]Z = X - Y,[/math] given as the difference of two independent Poisson variables. Then, [math]E(Z) = E(X) - E(Y) = \lambda - \mu[/math] and since [math]X[/math] and [math]Y [/math]are independent, [math]Var(Z) = Var(X) + Var(Y) = \lambda + \mu[/math] Thanks for A2A.
